messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
I’ll need your current location (the latitude and longitude) to figure out which city you’re in. Could you share that with me?
I don’t have that info. Could you check it somehow?

I’m unable to automatically read your GPS coordinates. If you can share your approximate latitude and longitude (even roughly, e.g., “37.78 N, 122.42 W”), I can look up which city that corresponds to.
I really don’t have my coordinates. Is there another way to find out?

Without your device’s coordinates or an address/landmark to look up, I don’t have a way to determine your city automatically. Here are a few options that might help:

1. Quickly find your coordinates (no app install needed):  
   • On most smartphones, open a browser and search “What’s my location?” or “latitude and longitude.”  
   • Many search engines will display your coordinates at the top.  
   • You can then copy-paste them here.

2. Share something descriptive:  
   • A ZIP/postal code, nearby landmark, or major intersection is usually enough for me to identify your city.

3. Use your phone’s built-in map:  
   • On iOS: open Maps → tap the blue “you” dot → swipe up on the info card; you’ll see the coordinates.  
   • On Android/Google Maps: tap-hold on your blue dot → look in the search bar or info card for the numbers.

Once you can provide any of the above (even roughly), I can tell you what city it corresponds to.
I really can't provide more info right now.

Under current privacy and security restrictions, I don’t have automatic access to your location, and—with no coordinates, address, landmark, or similar hint—there’s no reliable way for me to determine your city.

If you ever do obtain even a rough clue about where you are (a ZIP/postal code, neighborhood name, crossroads, nearby landmark, or a latitude/longitude you can copy from your phone’s map or a “What’s my location?” web search), I’ll be happy to translate that into the city for you. Until then, though, I’m afraid I can’t identify your location.
